Elamite

𒇽𒂊𒆷𒈬𒌑 LÚ.e-la-mu-ú

see Elam Susa 𜎒𜑰𜎂 Sušina @ Iran
see Medes

Linear Elamite is now (partly/almost) deciphered by Francois Desset and his team. Their recent paper lacks some of the great explanations and diagrams of earlier papers, it is highly recommended to read these as well, and watch a seminar https://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=desset+elamite.


Near identical building plans of the early temples and very similar early Egyptian and Sumerian ceremonies clearly demonstrate that these are not mere trade-artefacts, but in fact proof of a common anchestry of both higher civilizations. The connection with Susa is even stronger (cultic items, decimal numbers, …).

Before Elamite and Cuneiform diverged they had a very close semantic and pictographic correspondences:

Both used Sexagesimal counting except for Animals and Slaves which were counted Decimal in Susa!

𒆳 𒊩𒆳 𒊩 were near identical signs for workeslaves (𒊩 missed the 𒁹 in Susa)
𒋡 KA 𓂓 was combined with 𒊩 and 𒆳 in Susa and had a similar form (and meaning) in Uruk
𒇻 𒈧 𒈦 had a similar 𒈦 sign for shee goats, 𒇻 with horns appears in both (Susa round without 𒈦)
Vessels looked similar and were both combined with 𒆳 and 𒆜 KASKAL 𜎲 𜎳 𜎴 cheese?
𓌸 ploughs 𒀳 looked slightly similar to 𓍁, as did arrows 𒋾 (naturally)
𒀭 signified a low-status human in early Susa! Maybe as (¬high)servant, or as ethnic contrast to Uruk? (vs 𒈾!)

High status humans in Susa are tentative, abstract and have no equivalent in Uruk, one is combined with an animal, one looks a bit like 𔒴 another like 𐘃𓈙 in a box

Bisexagesimal numbering of grain products was similar

Unfortunately these common number tablets are absent from egypt, so that details of the common anchestries divergence are lost.

Numbers

Numbers in Elamite are unknown. Candidates: 𜓂 𜓃 𜓄 𜓅 𜓆 𜓇 𜓈 𜓉 𜓊 𜓋 𜓌 𜓍
The Syllabary itself uses very Mesopotamian numbers though: 5 vowels * 12 consonants = 60 syllables the proven basis of Proto-Elamite number tablets. Speculation: The external 5 'heavenly' vowels and 12 alphabetic signs may correspond to the 5 planets and 12 months/zodiacs/gods. Sun and Moon dont fit in this schema exept for the extra 'zero' whole. 0≈ø≈𓇳

Counting sheep UDU. IDIM .MES 𒇻𒅂𒈨𒌍 Widder = "planets" ( Akkadian bibbu ≈ 𒅂 )

3 𒀯 "Three Stars Each" per zodiac relevance?
5 planets
6 work days (modern concept), important multiplier in Sexagesimal system!
7 celestial bodies (planets, sun and moon)
10 Decans (36 decans)
12 dozen consonants (times two via ligature??)
12 zodiacs 𒀯 star groups (34) not attested until 1000BC **
12 year orbit of Jupiter along the ecliptic, used to define Babylonian zodiacs
13 cursed number (mixing 12 consonants with holy vocal row)
36 Egyptian decans form a year ( 66 / 312 / 310+6 )
60 A bi-monthly period of 60 days (six decans) constitutes a half-season ( minutes in hour )
100 𓅱 𓏲 10 decans, significance? counting 𓅱 Animals and Slaves.
360 Six half-seasons + 5 gods constitute a year ( seconds in hour )

** Sumerian or an Elamite(!) origin for these Babylonian constellations was proposed

The best evidence for early Mesopotamian constellations and star names still remains with texts dated to the 2nd-millennium BCE (circa 1800 BCE). There is no evidence of any established system of any of astral omens or astronomy in the Sumerian sources. There are no cuneiform texts from the 3rd-millennium BCE containing records of astronomical observations. However, the eminent assyriologist Hermann Hunger ("The Cultic Calendars of the Ancient Near East." in The Journal of the American Oriental Society, October-December, 1996) states: "While there is no doubt that the sky was observed in Sumerian times for the purpose of omens and probably also in connection with cultic actions, this is not astronomy, which involves measuring and computing." Systematic astronomical observations are not indicated as being part of Sumerian tradition. Their cosmology contains mythic elements. The extent to which Sumerian myths related to astronomical objects i.e., planets, remains uncertain.

Moon God

different strokes and dots may have different significance.

(Three) dots seem to be a simplified orthography for gunu!
since these two signs were identified as variants: 𜎰 𜓻
Evidence is given by the Indus gunification of 𜎋 𜎌 𜎖 𜎔 (𜢳 𜢹)
In all these it is also accompanied by vertical mirroring!
Also see 𜏰 𜏁, but not 𜏰 𜏯.

The 𜎠 nu might be a simplified 𜎧 gunu,
However 𜎲 and 𜎯 have different reconstructed values, disproving that theory.
Simplification of the gunu variants 𜐕 𜐔, 𜑤 𜑥 may suggest a 𒉺 P component, or is coincidental.

Ligatures, connections and Variants

subtleties do matter, so be very careful with premature "identification" of characters
Signs that look similar can be different and signs that look different on first sight can be homophones.

orthographic predictions based on cuneiform:

𜏼𜒇𜏌𜏳 sunkir
𜏃𜒉𜏌 sunki •cungi king
𜎄𜒉𜏌 zunki •cungi king
𜑇𜒉𜏌𜏳 zunkir

Unlike in Aegean scriptsl are distinguished.

du-ni-h ⋍= tu-ni-h I donated

Some orthographic variations hint at some distinctions between b [b] d [d] g [g] but in general these are NOT distinguished!.

Unless realized via doubling pp, t, kk, hh, šš, ll, rr, mm, nn un und Halbvoka are tentative

ḫ => h => ø in Neo Elamite

te-em-t te-ip-ti for tempti "lord" hint at nasalizations.

Grammar

Animate noun pronouns -suffixes

-k ik Fgo I "Locutive"
-t tF you "Alcokutive"
-r eF he "Decokutive"
-p plural who 𓊪𓍢
-ø neutrum

König "I, king"
Könit "You, king"
Köner "He, king"

X sunki-r hatamti-r ... "X, der König (sunki-) von Elam (hatamti-), ..."
u sunki-k hatamti-k ... "ich, der König von Elam, ..."

𜑐 needs special attention as its grammatical rule of -h/-š and 𜑐 ≈ 𓈉 #ḫst •ḫrst 3
𜑐 iš / ish / isch / ich < ego Icke Ecken 𜑐

Possessiv pronouns

1a. u₃-me von-mir ( LE u≠u₂ )
1b. u₃-pi of-I
1c. -i-pi-na ⋍ ip-na ⋍ upo o von I
2. nun nu-un ni-von
3. -r 𓆑 •ver for er

Ich ego ( Elamite )

𒅇 U3 ego ich in :

we ⋍ me ( Elamite )

𒅇𒉿 u₃-pi of-I ⇔ upon-I
𒅇𒈨 u₃-me of-me ( 𒅇 ego )

Inanimate 3rd noun suffixes

-Ø
-me ([sunki-me] “kingdom, kingship”)
-n ([siya-n] “temple,” [muru-n] “earth”)
-t ([hala-t] “clay, mud brick”)

Aus Postpositionen entwickelte Kasussuffixe gibt es erst in spätelamischer Zeit, die älteren Sprachstufen unterscheiden einen Kasus nur beim Personalpronomen (Nominativ und Akkusativ, siehe unten). Einen Artikel gibt es nicht. Das Elamische ist keine Ergativsprache, für transitive und intransitive Sätze werden dieselben Subjektformen verwendet.

Nominalphrasen haben immer die Reihenfolge Phrasenkopf - Attribut, wobei die Attribute Substantive (im Deutschen "Genitive"), Adjektive, Possessivpronomina und Relativsätze sein können. Bis auf die Relativsätze werden Attribute mit dem Phrasenkopf in der oben beschriebenen Art durch Kongruenzmarker verklammert.

u (TITEL) B kuši-h G1 ak G2 ap-u-i-n tuni-h
"ich (TITEL) B baute-ich (kuši-h), den Göttern G1 und G2 - ihnen (ap) ich (u) es (i-n) - gab-ich (tuni-h)"
"ich (TITEL) baute (Bauwerk) B und stiftete es den Göttern G1 und G2"

Die enklitische Partike markiert das Ende von Phrasen und Sätzen, satzeinleitende Partikel werden in den älteren Sprachstufen nur selten verwendet.

Alle Substantive werden im Elamischen zunächst in zwei Hauptklassen (grammatische Geschlechter) eingeteilt, nämlich der Personenklasse (PK) oder Sachklasse (SK).

ma marker

-me like akkadian -um and greek (…) ma aroma asthma coma comma enigma drama glaucoma lemma schema plasma trauma…

Der Marke- hat eine abstrahierende Funktion, wie die folgenden Beispiele zeigen:
sunki-me "Königtum" < sunki- "König" •cun'ki
lipa-me "Dienst" < lipa- "Diener" √labor
husa-me "Wald" < husa- "Holz, Baum" •huˡsa , Esche

5.5 Verbalstämme

Viele Wurzeln können im Elamischen nominal und verbal genutzt werden, z.B. me "Rückseite" und "folgen", tu "Eigentum" und "nehmen". Die meisten Verbalstämme enden auf einen Vokal, in den älteren Sprachphasen gibt es auch konsonantischen Auslaut.

Durch Reduplikation der Anlautsilbe können bei manchen Verben pluralisches Subjekt oder Objekt, aber auch "Pluralität" der Handlung (also ihre Wiederholung) ausgedrückt werden (Steiner 1990, allerdings ist diese Interpretation nicht allgemein anerkannt). Dabei kann es zu lautlichen Veränderungen kommen (z.B. Elision des Stammvokals). Einige Beispiele dieser Stammesmodifikationen durch Reduplikation der Anlautsilbe sind in der folgenden Tabelle zusammengestellt.

Beispiele von Verben mit Stammesmodifikation

Stamm
Einfach Modifiziert Bedeutung

li lili geben
ta tatta stellen
hapu hahpu hören
hutta huhta machen
kazza kaki schmieden
kela kekla befehlen
kuti kukti tragen
kuši kukši erbauen
peli pepli gründen
pera pepra lesen
turu tutri sagen
tallu tatallu schreiben

𐘨 𐚅 𐁔 Kyr Chyr=Gold OK? *47 A_28 PurOrQuarErx

Cuneiform Correspondences

Before Elamite and Cuneiform diverged they had a very close semantic and pictographic correspondences.

Vague cuneiform form correspondences, direct or complement (rotations etc)

The phonetics may match without the semantics, or vice versa.

Important to remember that all Akkadian signs as displayed in normal cuneiform fonts are rotated by 90°

Rotation is already rampant in Linear Elamite, so weak matches are independent of orientation.

Oftentimes an indirect connection can be established, despite graphic and phonetic divergence.

Many signs have clear Egyptian counterparts without (used) cuneiform antagonists 𜏵 𜏳 𓎫

best matches

See "all matches" for complete analysis and explanation

𒃰 GAN ubiquitous in Proto-Cuneiform and Proto-Elamite as ligature vessel is not identified yet.
𒃰 GAN is similar to 𜒣 sometimes, but sometimes left open. Maybe open form eradicated in simplification process.
See anatolian for open versus closed forms.

Attested signs

## Unicode private block 0XE000
There are 357 distinctive signs attested in the extant sources:

Syn & Sum

Since this syllabary was certainly practised like our ABC, we might look into poetry with similar metric:
5 morae
̄ ̆ ̄ cretic
̆ ̄ ̄ bacchius
6 morae
̄ ̆ ̆ ̄ choriamb
̆ ̆ ̄ ̄ ionic (a minore)

𒈱]][[𒋞

𜎅 me
The value me for is additionally confirmed by the fact that both the cuneiform Elamite syllable me (the suffix for abstract nouns) and the LE sign are optional in their actual use: cuneiform Elamite shows free variation between kušik-me u-me vs. kušik u-me “my construction” or sunki-me u-me vs. sunki u-me “my kingdom.” This pattern is reflected in LE sequences like vs. (Mäder et al. 2018: tabs. 12–14).

𐦊 ⋍ 𒐏 NIMIN
𐦊 ≈ 𓋞 ♒︎ Nabu 𒀭𒀝
𐦊 nauti 𐊾 ND carian letter

piṭātu
Use of pí, Egyptian archers

The archers were part of the Egyptian army, and often requested by the Canaanite vassal city-states, when writing to the Pharaoh in the Amarna letters. They were named the pitati, Akkadian language "piṭātu",[6] "troops of soldiers", and spelled in a variety of ways, often starting with the bi sign as pí.

A partial listing of spellings of "ERIM.MEŠ-pitati", by Amarna letter:

𓊪 𓏏 𓊪 𓏏 𓀜 | trample (enemies) | piétiner √pod ƥotƥot 2-feet defeat / kaputt +++
𓊪 𓏏 𓊪 𓏏 𓂻 | tread (roads), trample (enemies) | √pod piétiner (kaput) +++

The Shimashki or Simashki dynasty (𒈗𒂊𒋛𒈦𒄀𒆠, lugal-ene si-mash-giki "Kings of the country of Simashgi"), was an early dynasty of the ancient region of Elam, to the southeast of Babylonia, in approximately 2100-1900 BCE.

𜏠𜑊𜎮 𜒚𜎺𜎮 𜐾𜏳𜎅 𜑤𜒐𜒜𜎮 𜏇𜎅𜏂𜐲𜎂 ma-ni-p sa-hi-p hu-r-t ki-ri-pu-p hu-t-ta-k-na 𒈠𒉌𒄿𒉿 𒊓𒄭𒄿𒉿 𒄷𒌫tu3 𒄀𒊑𒉿 𒌒 𒄷𒌓𒋫𒀝𒈾 ma-ni-i-pi sa-hi-i-pi hu-ur2-tu3 ki2-ri-pi up hu-ut-ta-ak-na /manip sahip hurt kerep op hutakna/ “May the manis(?) of bronze be realized for my priests.”

𜏠 𜑊 𜎮 ma-ni-p 𒈠𒉌𒄿𒉿 ma-ni-i “manis” a cultic object of bronze manis ≈ 𓏠 𓈖 𓏴 𓏌 | ( 𜏠 ma ≈ 𒈾 na ) manis ≈ 𓏠 𓈖 𓏴 𓏌 | jar | 𜏠 𜑊 𜎮 manis ≈ 𓏠 𓈖 𓇋 𓏋 | jar, measure of capacity | manis ≈ 𓏠 𓈖 𓇋 𓏴 𓏌 | jar, measure of capacity | manis ≈ 𓏠 𓈖 𓈎 𓏏 𓏋 | jar ? | manis ≈ 𓏠 𓈖 𓎂 𓎿 | jar (for liquids) | manis ≈ 𓏠 𓈖 𓈙 𓍷 | cartouche ? manis ≈ 𓏠 𓈖 𓏌 𓅂 | monuments ? manis ≈ 𓏠 𓈖 𓐍 𓏏 𓋳 armament ? <> 𓏠 𓈖 𓏛 | be firm 9.660 copper, bronze 𒂊𒊑𒉌;𒊓𒄴;𒊓𒄭𒄿;𒋛𒄭𒆕 e-ri-ni; sa-h; sa-hi-i; si-hi-kak
